blocks.text:
The general solution is: 

$$y = -a + b \sqrt{4 - \delta}$$ 

and let 

$$\lambda_1 = -a + \sqrt{4 - \delta}$$ 

$$\lambda_2 = -a - \sqrt{4 - \delta}$$ 

We shall now discuss the three cases. 

Case (i): If \( \delta = 0 \), then \( \lambda_1 \) and \( \lambda_2 \) are real quantities and unequal. 

Case (ii): If \( \delta > 0 \), then \( \lambda_1 \) and \( \lambda_2 \) will equal 0, as the two roots are equal if \( \delta = 0 \), such that to complete the solution the roots can be calculated (either or both are needed). 

Thus 

$$\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 = -a \pm b \sqrt{\delta}$$ 

the constants \( A_1 \) and \( A_2 \) being fixed by the conditions. 

Case (iii): If \( \delta < 0 \), then \( \lambda_1 \) and \( \lambda_2 \) are complex. According to the preceding case we might suppose that the solution was 

$$y = A e^{\lambda_1 x} + B e^{\lambda_2 x}$$ 

This, however, is not the complete solution, which is 

$$\lambda = A \exp(B x) + C \exp(\text{[UNRECOGNIZED TEXT]})$$ 

This means that \( \lambda_1 \) is the square root of a negative quantity, i.e., it is an imaginary. 

Now, \( \lambda_1 = -a - \sqrt{-1} \text{[UNRECOGNIZED TEXT]} = \delta \) being positive; hence 

$$\lambda_1 = -a + \sqrt{-1 - \sqrt{-a^2}}$$ 

You might have made the solution to Case (i), adopting these values of \( \lambda_1 \) and \( \lambda_2 \) but this does not prove the most convenient form in which to write the solution. 

Let \( z = \sqrt{-b}$$
